etymologies: Old English ān, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch een and German ein, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin unus. The initial w sound developed before the 15th century and was occasionally represented in the spelling; it was not accepted into standard English until the late 17th century

notes.text: In modern English, the use of one as a pronoun to mean ‘anyone’ or ‘me and people in general,’ as in one must try one's best, is generally restricted to formal contexts, outside which it is likely to be regarded as rather pompous or old-fashioned. In informal and spoken contexts, the normal alternative is you, as in you have to do what you can, don't you?

definitions: the lowest cardinal number; half of two; 1

examples.text: there's only room for one person
two could live as cheaply as one
one hundred miles
World War One
a one-bedroom apartment

definitions: a single person or thing, viewed as taking the place of a group

examples.text: they would straggle home in ones and twos

definitions: single; just one as opposed to any more or to none at all (used for emphasis)

examples.text: her one concern is to save her daughter

definitions: denoting a particular item of a pair or number of items

examples.text: electronics is one of his hobbies
he put one hand over her shoulder and one around her waist
a glass tube closed at one end

definitions: denoting a particular but unspecified occasion or period

examples.text: one afternoon in late October

definitions: used before a name to denote a person who is not familiar or has not been previously mentioned; a certain

examples.text: he worked as a clerk for one Mr. Ming

definitions: a noteworthy example of (used for emphasis)

examples.text: the actor was one smart-mouthed troublemaker
he was one hell of a snappy dresser
all types of training meet one common standard
it's half past one
I'll be there at one
a cool one after a day on the water
the one about the chicken farmer and the spaceship

definitions: a size of garment or other merchandise denoted by one.
shortDefinitions: size of garment denoted by one

definitions: a domino or dice with one spot.
shortDefinitions: domino or dice with one spot

notes.text: In modern English, the use of one as a pronoun to mean ‘anyone’ or ‘me and people in general,’ as in one must try one's best, is generally restricted to formal contexts, outside which it is likely to be regarded as rather pompous or old-fashioned. In informal and spoken contexts, the normal alternative is you, as in you have to do what you can, don't you?

definitions: referring to a person or thing previously mentioned or easily identified

examples.text: her mood changed from one of moroseness to one of joy
her best apron, the white one
do you want one?

shortDefinitions: referring to person or thing previously mentioned

definitions: a person of a specified kind

examples.text: you're the one who ruined her life
my friends and loved ones
Eleanor was never one to be trifled with

definitions: a person who is remarkable or extraordinary in some way

examples.text: you never saw such a one for figures

definitions: used to refer to the speaker, or any person, as representing people in general

examples.text: one must admire him for his willingness
one gets the impression that he is ahead
